description.narrative: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1.1 Number of new data sources used at country level 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over different hypotheses
2.1 learning the Accelerator lab share with outside audience (outside UNDP)
2.2 Number of lab’s insights, processes, products which are taken up by government or other partners 2.3 Proportion o partners and governments that increase their uptake of the innovation methods included in the accelerator lab network 2.4 Proportion of UNDP country office programming influenced by the accelerator lab Network’s work and methodologies
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among accelerator labs Number of new models, approaches, insights documented and disseminated through the network 3.2 Engagement of the broader development ecosystem with published learning from the accelerator lab 3.3 Amount of the influence and learnings and methods of the accelerator lab network on the discourse of the broader development ecosystem

comment.narrative:
1.1 10 new data sources per year
1.2 9 different types of data sources per year
1.3 50 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 10 innovation methods per action plan
2.1 At lest 8 blogs or other (Substantial ) media posts published per year 2.2 at least 50% of our learning challenges has the public sector or other counter part 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has or is in the process of adopting accelerator lab method 2.4 at least 75% of learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects
3.1 50% of information shared across the network should be methodology or sustainable development issues and opportunity related 3.2 The Accelerator lab work is featured at least 3 times per month in country office social media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator lab accounts/The lab team at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator lab network , from either persona or CO account 3.3 Connect Accelerator lab’s publication to local development ecosystems through social media /identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the development ecosystem.

1) Five new data sources were investigated and used, including GIS data, Open Data, web scraped data, drone data, and big data, all of which were used in different learning cycles. 2) In all of its yearly learning cycles, the lab used geographic information systems data, drone data, and web scraped data. 3) 50 new solutions have been mapped and uploaded to the innovate map. http://innovate.co.tz/app/ and in the accelerator lab global solution platform 4) Design thinking, solutions mapping, co-creation, distributed problem solving, hackathon/maker thon, and ethnography were among the 6 innovation methods used. 5) 3 blogs were published, with five more in the works. 6) All of the learning challenges were completed in collaboration with other partners, including Mwanza City Council (Solid waste management challenge), Dar Es Salaam Institute of Technology, Robotech, Bits and Bytes, Uhuru Labs, and UNDP Innovation Center (Singapore) (3D printing), Xsense AI (Private)- Artificial Intelligence, the Zanzibar Association of Tour Operators (ZATO), the Zanzibar Association of Tourism Investors, and the Zanzibar (ZCT) – AI and GIS in tourism).Other private-sector partners included the Science and Technology Commission, the Nelson Mandela African Institution for Science and Technology, and the Mbeya University of Science and Technology. 7) The Dar Es Salaam Technology and Business Incubator (DTBI) has expressed verbal interest in implementing lab methodologies, including replicating the lab structure in government corridors 8) At least 75% of learning challenges contribute actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 9) Learning challenges centered on 3D printing, artificial intelligence, and the use of satellite imagery, GIS, and distributed problem solving - provided the necessary intelligence to the CO programs, eventually leading to the redesign of some programs to incorporate lab methodologies, such as the use of local knowledge, GIS, and drone imagery data to aid in tourism recovery and resilience in Zanzibar. 10) All experiments and explorations were carried out in accordance with the Country Programme Document and the UNDAP, and thus addressed sustainable development issues such as Inclusive Growth and Poverty Reduction, Environmental Sustainability, Climate Change and Resilience, and Inclusive Democratic Governance. Methodologically, the issues discussed were related to the use of Lab methods and approaches such as solution mapping, exploration, co-creation, and distributed problem solving. 11) The lab was featured in multiple social media profiles of prominent ecosystem actors, particularly those related to learning challenges, such as 3D printing, AI, and SWM partners, such as @ailab and @OMDTZ. Furthermore, the labs content was frequently featured on the Twitter accounts of the partners mentioned in section 2.2 above. 12) The lab collaborated with labs in Panama, Ghana, Kenya, Rwanda, Libya, and Malawi, among others.

1.1 2 new data sources per year
1.2 3 different types of data sources per year
1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year
1.4 2 innovation methods per action plan
2.1 At least 3 blogs or other (Substantial) media posts published per year 2.2 at least 50% of our learning challenges has the public sector or other counter part 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has or is in the process of adopting accelerator lab method 2.4 at least 50% of learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects
3.1 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology or sustainable development issues and opportunity related 3.2 The Accelerator lab work is featured at least 2 times per month in country office social media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator lab accounts/The lab team at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator lab network, from either persona or CO account
3.3 Connect Accelerator lab’s publication to local development ecosystems through social media /identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the development ecosystem
3.4 The lab interacts with another lab at least once per week

1) The lab investigated and planned to use satellite data, open and financial market data from the Solid Waste Management Project, as well as data from the Tanzania commodity exchange market. 2) Initially, satellite data, open data, and crowd data were used to build up projects to answer to the years two objectives, which included using satellite imaging to improve solid waste management data and speeding the usage of the Tanzania mercantile exchange commodity market for cash crops.
3) Approximately 30 additional potential solutions were identified.
4) Design Thinking and Problem-Solving Mapping techniques were used to not only explore and map prospective lab solutions, but also to construct potential entrance points to promote the creation of unique approaches to dealing with solid waste management concerns. In the city of Mwanza
5) Five blogs were written in 2019 and will be published in early 2020 (https://www.tz.undp.org/content/tanzania/en/home/blog.htm ). The country offices official Twitter profile, @undptz, and the personal accounts of lab members, @nyandaPN, @Ghati20061, and @Godnyam, were used to share lab activities.
6) In 2019, the lab collaborated with the Mwanza City Council (North Tanzania) to investigate solutions to deal with the complexities of solid waste management utilizing collective intelligence methods. The lab collaborated directly with the Environment and Sanitation Department.
7) Three Lab members had only joined UNDP in September 2019, thus 3 months may not have been long enough to detect interest in employing lab methods by other parties; yet, there was a great degree of enthusiasm to understand what the lab was and what it attempted to achieve.
8) Design thinking and solution mapping methodologies contributed a significant amount of information and interest to the country office project. The experiment around solid waste management design was influenced by an ongoing CO initiative that offered technical and financial support to the City Council to develop its own investment guide- a blueprint providing investment information to prospective local and foreign investors with the goal of attracting them to exploit investment potentials in the region in order to stimulate business and enterprise development as well as execute development pathways
9) Explorations in 2019 were conducted in accordance with the Country Programme Document and the UNDAP II, and thus addressed sustainable development issues such as Inclusive Growth and Poverty Reduction, Environmental Sustainability, Climate Change and Resilience, and Inclusive Democratic Governance in accordance with country priorities.
10) Lab activities were communicated via the Country Offices official Twitter account, @undptz, as well as personal lab members accounts, @nyandaPN, @Ghati20061, and @Godnyam.
11) The lab was included in numerous social media profiles of key ecosystem actors, particularly those associated to exploration and mapping, such as the Sahara sparks and the Tanzania Innovation Week platform.
12) The lab interacted with the Malawi lab more regularly and with another lab across the network on a regular basis.

1.1 5 new data sources per year
1.2 6 different types of data sources per year
1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per action plan
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (Substantial) media posts published per year 2.2 at least 50% of our learning challenges has the public sector or other counter part 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has or is in the process of adopting accelerator lab method 2.4 at least 50% of learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects
3.1 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology or sustainable development issues and opportunity related 3.2 The Accelerator lab work is featured at least 3 times per month in country office social media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator lab accounts/The lab team at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator lab network, from either persona or CO account 3.3 Connect Accelerator lab’s publication to local development ecosystems through social media /identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the development ecosystem. 3.4 The lab interacts with another lab at least once per week

1) The lab used social media data, GIS data, Open Data, Satellite data, and financial markets data to accelerate the use of the commodity exchange market, improve solid waste management data, and use AI to combat online misinformation. 2) 5 data sources were used, including social media data, financial market data, citizen generated data, and satellite imagery data, as well as exploration into using big data to improve government revenue collection was undertaken. 3) 40 new potential solutions were mapped and uploaded to the crowdsourcing platform Innovators Map Tanzania (innovate.co.tz) 4) 4 methods of innovation were used: design thinking, solutions mapping, co-creation, distributed problem solving, and hackathon/maker thon. 5) 6 blogs have been published on the UNDP website and tagged on the Accelerator lab blog page. The blogs were also shared on Twitter via the COs official page @undptz. 6) 100% of learning challenges were completed in collaboration with other partners such as Mwanza City Council (Solid waste management challenge), Dar Es Salaam Institute of Technology, Robotech, Bits and Bytes, Uhuru labs and UNDP Innovation centre (Singapore) (3D printing), Tanzania Merchantile exchange (Agriculture), Sense AI (Private), Artificial Intelligence. 7) The Mwanza City Council and the Tanzania Commission for Science and Technology have expressed verbal interest in adopting the lab’s methods and approaches. 8) Learning challenges centred on 3D printing, artificial intelligence, and the use of satellite imagery provided the necessary intelligence to the CO programs, eventually leading to the redesign of some programs to incorporate lab methodologies, such as the use of local knowledge, GIS, and drone imagery data to aid in tourism recovery and resilience in Zanzibar (Existing programme) 9) 100% of learning cycles were conducted in line with the Country Programme Document and the UNDAP, they addressed sustainable development issues such as Inclusive Growth and Poverty Reduction, Environmental Sustainability, Climate Change and Resilience, and Inclusive Democratic Governance. Methodologically, the issues discussed were related to the use of Lab methods and approaches such as solution mapping, exploration, co-creation, and distributed problem solving. 10) Lab activities were shared on the Country Offices official Twitter page, @undptz, as well as personal lab member accounts, @nyandaPN, @Ghati20061, and @Godnyam, and later the newly opened Instagram page, @undptz. 11) The lab was featured in multiple social media profiles of prominent ecosystem actors, particularly those related to learning challenges, such as 3D printing, AI, and SWM partners, such as @ailab and @OMDTZ. 12) The lab collaborated with labs from all over Africa, including Panama, Ghana, Kenya, Rwanda, and Malawi.
